subject: Real Estate
title: Zillow and the Price of Transparency
description: A micro-lesson that makes Zillow and the Price of Transparency usable.

hook.text: Before 2006, home values were a secret. You needed an agent just to see what a house might cost.

buildup.text: Zillow launched the Zestimate â€” an algorithm that guessed any home's value using public data.

discovery.text: Suddenly, 100 million homeowners could see what their property was supposedly worth, for free.

twist.text: Agents hated it. Zestimates were often wrong by 5â€“10%, yet buyers treated them as gospel.

climax.text: Transparency shifted power from agents to consumers. Information asymmetry shrank overnight.

punchline.text: An algorithm changed who controls property data.
